title: Episode 71 â€“ Karenna Gore, Director, Center for Earth Ethics
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: But let me first pause quickly to thank some of our sponsors and to remind our audience this is the YonEarth community podcast.
full_transcript:
[5.2s - 12.2s]: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron Perry. And today we're

[12.2s - 20.8s]: visiting with Karenna Gore. Hey, Karenna. Hi, Aaron. Thank you so much for having me on

[20.8s - 27.7s]: the Y on Earth Podcast, which is great. It's a real pleasure. And I'm thrilled we can

[27.7s - 35.7s]: talk with you, especially given what's going on in the world right now. And I want to get to that.

[35.8s - 45.0s]: But first, let me introduce you to our audience for those who don't know you yet. So Karenna Gore is

[45.0s - 51.7s]: the founder and director of the Center for Earth Ethics at Union Theological Seminary. The Center

[51.7s - 59.1s]: for Earth Ethics bridges the worlds of religion, academia, policy, and culture to discern and pursue

[59.1s - 65.3s]: the changes that are necessary to stop ecological destruction and create a society that values the

[65.3s - 73.5s]: long-term health of the whole. She is also an ex-officio member of the Faculty of the Earth Institute

[73.5s - 80.2s]: at Columbia University. Ms. Gore's previous experience includes serving as Director of Union

[80.2s - 87.5s]: Forum at Union Theological Seminary, legal work at Simpson, Thacher, and Bartlett in the legal center

[87.5s - 93.8s]: of sanctuary for families and serving as Director of Community Affairs for the Association to

[93.8s - 101.3s]: Benefit Children and River Keeper. She has also worked as a writer and as the author of Lighting the

[101.3s - 107.5s]: Way, Nine Women who changed modern America. Ms. Gore is a graduate of Harvard College, Columbia

[107.5s - 113.1s]: Law School, and Union Theological Seminary. She lives in New York City with her three children.

[113.3s - 119.4s]: Now, you live in New York City ordinarily, but presently you're not there because why? What's

[119.4s - 130.7s]: going on in the world? Well, in this time, this pandemic of COVID-19, coronavirus,

[131.5s - 140.3s]: when the school shut down and people were asked to work remotely, I'm one of those and well aware of

[140.3s - 149.0s]: the privileged nature of this who was able to go out of the city to a place in the Catskills.

[150.6s - 157.8s]: That I have shared with my former husband and I have my kids up here that are doing school

[157.8s - 164.5s]: from up here and I'm doing work from up here. So I'm in the Catskills and the Western Catskills

[164.5s - 171.8s]: and I apologize if the Wi-Fi drops off by the way because it is a bit spotty, but that's where I am

[171.8s - 179.1s]: and I really appreciate being able to spend this time with you and your viewers when we can

[179.1s - 185.1s]: really reflect on so much that's going on right now in the world. Yeah, absolutely, Karen,

[185.1s - 189.7s]: and I just want to give a little teaser to the audience that we're going to be sharing some

[189.7s - 196.5s]: special projects and links a little later in the discussion that are going live right now

[196.5s - 203.1s]: in the context of corona and COVID and everything that's happening. So I want to make sure folks

[203.8s - 210.3s]: catch that and it's so interesting to me too that so much of your work centers around

[210.3s - 217.8s]: relationship with Earth, with planet, with biosphere and you do that from one of the largest and

[217.8s - 223.7s]: most densely populated cities in the world, certainly in the United States. And I'm just curious

[223.7s - 231.8s]: as a way to kind of give us grounded in our discussion today, what does Earth ethics mean?

[231.8s - 235.0s]: And what does that mean in the context of education?

[238.1s - 246.6s]: Well, thank you for that question. Ethics is defined differently depending on who's doing the ethics,

[247.2s - 255.4s]: but essentially it is questions of right and wrong or good and evil or just or unjust.

[256.5s - 264.3s]: It's different from law. In some we want our ethics to match up with our laws, it's wrong to

[264.3s - 273.4s]: kill someone, it's also illegal, but ethics is also, it's really most important during those times

[274.1s - 280.8s]: when deep sense of right and wrong is out of step with the law and also out of step with

[280.8s - 288.2s]: social norms, which is another component that we look at. So right now with the circumstances

[288.2s - 296.1s]: that were in ecologically, we have to acknowledge and face the fact that the drivers of ecological

[296.1s - 303.5s]: destruction are for the most part perfectly legal and in line with social norms. So ethics

[303.5s - 312.0s]: becomes especially important in terms of thinking about the Earth, how we relate to nature, to this

[312.0s - 318.5s]: planet. We are coming up on the anniversary, the 50th anniversary of the first Earth Day.

[319.3s - 331.2s]: And we're in a situation where we have a looming climate crisis. I was born in the early 1970s and

[332.0s - 339.0s]: in my lifetime the human population has doubled and the population of wildlife has been cut in half.

[339.7s - 346.4s]: We've lost about half the world's forests. We know the bleaching of the coral reefs and the

[346.4s - 356.9s]: depletion of aquifers of groundwater. We face an extinction crisis. There are so many ways in which

[356.9s - 362.5s]: are the way our society is organized right now is putting great strain on the Earth. And so Earth

[362.5s - 370.7s]: ethics looks at that. And there are some deep roots to how we got here. And I know you've explored

[370.7s - 378.8s]: some of this on your other podcasts. So we look at those and think about what is the circle of moral

[378.8s - 386.5s]: concern that people normally think about? And I have a friend at the Church of Sweden who says that

[386.5s - 393.5s]: in any room where there are decisions made about energy policy, environmental policy, there should

[393.5s - 401.3s]: be three empty chairs designated for those who are most impacted and least likely to have a voice.

[401.9s - 407.8s]: And those should be for the poor and marginalized peoples of the world, for future generations,

[408.5s - 415.9s]: and for all non-human life. And when you think about it, if we had paid attention to those three,

[416.5s - 423.9s]: we would not be in this crisis. So Earth ethics is a construct to think about how do we change

[424.7s - 429.9s]: who we're paying attention to that sense of moral accountability to include those three empty chairs?

[430.5s - 437.7s]: In terms of education, it is also a very big challenge to try to conceive of how we can become

[437.7s - 445.6s]: ecological citizens in this world. Many people don't know, for example, what watershed they're in,

[446.6s - 451.4s]: where the waste goes that you throw out in the garbage or you flush down the toilet,

[451.9s - 457.4s]: where the power comes from when you turn on the lights. And yet these are all connected

[458.4s - 464.5s]: to ecological realities and systems and to other communities that if we're more aware of,

[465.0s - 468.0s]: then we'll be able to change for the better.

[469.4s - 477.3s]: It's so interesting to recognize and talk about and make express that in many respects,

[478.0s - 482.8s]: what we might be compelled to do, what we might find to be a moral imperative,

[483.5s - 488.7s]: doesn't necessarily match with social norms. And it makes me think about the civil rights movement,

[489.4s - 496.7s]: especially around the middle of the 20th century. And with amazing leaders and a whole bunch of

[496.7s - 503.1s]: dedicated individuals whose names we don't know as well as somebody like Reverend Martin Luther King,

[503.1s - 508.4s]: for example, it was the hard work of a whole lot of folks in a lot of different communities

[508.4s - 514.3s]: who helped to transform the social norms. And of course, it doesn't have an overnight,

[514.3s - 521.1s]: it's not like flipping a switch, but I think it's fair to say that we've made some very real progress

[521.7s - 528.2s]: on that front and that it might provide a hopeful pattern for us to think about in terms of

[528.2s - 538.0s]: the ecological challenges that we're facing. Absolutely. I think that's a very rich connection to

[538.0s - 545.3s]: draw. And it is indeed a time when we can think about that the deep sense of right and wrong

[545.3s - 550.8s]: was out of step with laws and with social norms. And so some of the movements, the lunch counter

[550.8s - 558.9s]: sit-ins, the freedom rides were about unmasking the unjustness, the unethical nature of those laws.

[559.9s - 566.7s]: And there were, as you say, people behind the scenes or in the grassroots layer of that movement,

[567.2s - 575.2s]: like Septima Clark is one example who ran citizenship schools in the south and the people that

[575.2s - 584.5s]: went through and trained to know basic civic rights and also strategies of solidarity,

[585.1s - 589.8s]: of coordinating, of organizing among the people that went through those classes was Rosa Parks.

[590.7s - 596.1s]: Another one was John Lewis. So there are people who didn't come out of nowhere, they came through

[596.1s - 604.4s]: a movement and a type of education that was not at all top down, not at all based in kind of a

[604.4s - 612.6s]: ivory tower academy, but based in generating consciousness and knowledge and experience among people.

[613.1s - 620.1s]: So if we take that example in this time of ecological crisis, then we might be able to do the same thing.

[620.5s - 626.0s]: Another thing about drawing that connection to the civil rights movement is to consider the role

[626.0s - 633.5s]: that religion played. So we're based at a seminary, the Center for Earth Ethics, and it has a very

[633.5s - 640.8s]: interfaith tradition within it. And we don't forward one religious point of view, but we take religion

[640.8s - 647.6s]: very seriously for a few reasons. For one thing, we look not only at the role of religion for good,

[647.8s - 653.1s]: but also the role that it's played for ill. And there are some real theological questions

[653.1s - 659.4s]: about the illusion of our separation from nature, how we even talk about climate and environment,

[659.4s - 666.0s]: and sometimes we haven't recognized that it's actually the air and the water and the soil that are

[666.0s - 671.5s]: part of our bodies. But another thing about engaging religion is to look at what moves and

[671.5s - 678.3s]: motivates people in their behavior, what can draw from deeper values. And of course, in the civil rights

[678.3s - 684.7s]: movement, we saw that. We saw that from the language that came as well as from the organizing spaces

[685.6s - 690.5s]: in the churches. And of course, that was especially true in the African-American community.

[691.2s - 699.3s]: But across the board, abolitionism and civil rights organizing started also in white and black

[699.3s - 704.0s]: communities in spaces where people were drawing from deep within faith traditions.

[705.1s - 711.2s]: Yeah, so beautiful. Wow, you just got me firing in a bunch of different directions at once,

[711.2s - 716.1s]: hearing you connect these dots the way that you just did. That's really wonderful and potent.

[716.4s - 724.1s]: And it strikes me that one of the most significant challenges and opportunities we face in the west,

[724.3s - 732.1s]: particularly in the United States, is really recognizing the deep roots of the philosophical,

[732.1s - 740.4s]: the religious disconnection from the natural living world. And of course, there's a whole bunch of

[740.4s - 748.1s]: literature, scholarship on how that relates both to environmental degradation and incredible social

[749.1s - 754.1s]: injustice. And whether we're looking at the very challenging,

[755.2s - 763.7s]: derisive critique of Nietzsche 140 or 50 years ago, or looking at more recently the beautiful book

[763.7s - 770.7s]: by Thomas Barry called, what is it, the fate of the earth in the Christian future or something like that?

[771.8s - 776.0s]: There's the dream that we were going to make the great work. Yeah.

[776.4s - 782.6s]: Yeah, there's this very big conversation that's been unfolding over generations.

[783.5s - 792.3s]: And it seems to me we're now living at a moment when how this conversation unfolds and in a sense

[792.3s - 799.9s]: resolves itself in the next few years is incredibly significant in determining what our

[799.9s - 806.7s]: near and midterm future is going to look like. And I'm curious in your role as an educator,

[807.9s - 814.9s]: how deep do you go into that history? How far back do you go? What threads are you pulling through

[814.9s - 819.8s]: for your students to help awaken them to the reality that we're living in right now?

[822.5s - 829.5s]: Oh, thank you. Well, I, and I know of your interest in this and I've heard you speak and

[829.5s - 835.9s]: and interview others and so I really appreciate your work on this Aaron and happy to

[835.9s - 844.8s]: to be part of that conversation. Well, for one thing, let me just say that the Center for

[844.8s - 851.3s]: Earth Ethics really grew out of this conference that we had. I went to Union and got a master's

[851.3s - 857.8s]: kind of mid-life mid-career and then I had a general public programming job there and

[858.3s - 862.3s]: we're based as a seminary based in New York City. So the idea was that when the United Nations

[862.3s - 869.0s]: meets every year, perhaps we could have something at Union that deals with religion and spirituality

[869.6s - 875.0s]: and how it's affected how it relates to whatever the UN happens to be focused on.

[876.1s - 884.9s]: Because the UN for good reasons, mostly doesn't directly engage religion but religion drives so much

[884.9s - 891.4s]: in the world, both for good and ill. And so anyway, I was there in September 2014,

[891.8s - 897.7s]: the Secretary General at the time, Bon Kimu, called the Climate Summit. It happens now every year,

[897.7s - 906.2s]: but to engage civil society because this climate crisis is so urgent and yet governments haven't

[906.2s - 911.5s]: been able to, this was before the Paris Agreement, get it together to get that agreement and the

[911.5s - 915.7s]: idea was to engage civil society, including which includes business, it includes different sectors,

[915.7s - 919.7s]: but religion was one component. So we were able to have this conference at Union,

[920.4s - 925.6s]: called Religions for the Earth. And I was an organizer of that. And after that,

[926.5s - 934.1s]: we founded the center. So I tell you that background because I wanted to be able to engage

[934.1s - 942.5s]: and interreligious dialogue in a good way. And it was very clear that Indigenous traditions were

[943.7s - 949.6s]: important to that and had not always been included in conventional interfaith dialogue.

[950.2s - 955.4s]: So looking at the history, having some of those conversations, doing some of that reading,

[955.5s - 962.9s]: looking more closely at the history of colonization and its relationship to ecological destruction,

[964.6s - 971.7s]: caused me to understand the history of the doctrine of discovery in this country.

[972.7s - 984.4s]: And that comes out of the fact that in the mid-15th century, the European nations were wanting to

[985.6s - 994.2s]: explore and colonize and extract from, particularly the Americas and Africa. And from the Vatican,

[994.2s - 1002.4s]: there was this papal that was that series of them that said to conquer vanquishing subdued

[1003.1s - 1008.7s]: all the flora and fauna and said that the non-Christian people, meaning all the native people,

[1008.9s - 1018.0s]: were part of the flora and fauna. So we look at that as a root cause of this sense,

[1018.0s - 1026.3s]: first of all, connecting white supremacy to ecological destruction and the theology behind it,

[1026.4s - 1032.8s]: because it was explicitly coming from a place of Christianity. So that's important. Then if you go

[1032.8s - 1040.6s]: deeper back in time even, it's very interesting to look at how this happened in the first place

[1041.5s - 1047.9s]: with the conversion of the emperor Constantine, the Roman emperor to Christianity in the early fourth

[1047.9s - 1057.3s]: century. So that became the marriage of Christianity, which as we know, this wasn't the teachings of

[1057.3s - 1066.3s]: Jesus or the texts of the Bible. We're not already linked to this kind of empire and colonization

[1066.3s - 1071.7s]: behaviors, but the, although you can have an interesting discussion about the theology there,

[1072.2s - 1082.3s]: but in an event when Constantine converted and there was this push to make, to Christianize Europe,

[1083.2s - 1088.6s]: we can look at one source in particular that I think is really interesting. And many people

[1088.6s - 1094.7s]: know it already, but it's called, there was an essay in 1967 by a medieval historian named Lin

[1094.7s - 1102.2s]: White, who wrote the historic roots of our ecological crisis. And he said in that essay that the greatest

[1103.3s - 1109.9s]: psychic revolution in human history was the victory of Christianity over paganism in Europe.

[1110.5s - 1117.5s]: And so that takes it back even further in time than the doctrine of discovery to show the theological

[1117.5s - 1126.2s]: roots of a kind of doctrine that said that what is sacred cannot see your landscape as sacred, your

[1126.2s - 1134.4s]: ceremonies, a kind of fear and of paganism. And you still see that in a lot of the conversations

[1134.4s - 1139.9s]: and the kind of culture war that people have developed around environmentalism or concern for

[1139.9s - 1146.3s]: the climate that somehow your tree hugger, that your worshipping nature. And that is that deep

[1146.3s - 1155.1s]: fear of paganism that goes that far back. So we try to look at, we try to look at those histories

[1155.1s - 1162.8s]: in order to see where that's coming from in order to look clearly at the role that the church

[1162.8s - 1168.9s]: has played, which of course is not all for ill. There has been a lot of really beautiful theology

[1168.9s - 1177.5s]: and work within Christianity and other religions. But in a classroom, so we do, we give classes at

[1177.5s - 1181.5s]: union. That's one thing that we're able to do. And it's wonderful to work with union students.

[1182.1s - 1187.2s]: So we can do that, we can do that reading, and then we can also talk to people who are living in

[1187.2s - 1193.2s]: communities now. And that's really what's most important is to hear from people, for example,

[1193.2s - 1198.9s]: when the conflict at Standing Rock happened some years ago. And we could hear from

[1199.6s - 1205.9s]: Lakota people who wanted to voice what that was about from their perspective. So we try to combine

[1205.9s - 1213.0s]: lived experiences with those scholarly texts and look at the root causes and then create

[1213.0s - 1221.8s]: earth ethics from there. It's absolutely beautiful. So beautiful. You have me reflecting on my own

[1221.8s - 1230.1s]: heritage. And one of the things I've noticed talking with different folks is that in many communities,

[1230.1s - 1237.5s]: when we're talking about indigenous peoples, when we're talking about colonialism, for a lot of us,

[1237.5s - 1245.7s]: that's this experience that's way over there with people we don't know, or folks were not connected to.

[1246.6s - 1254.5s]: And being the ad mixture of different lineages that I am, which include some mohawk Native American

[1255.1s - 1262.2s]: ancestry, some Slovenian ancestry, some German ancestry, some Celtic ancestry. As I have dug

[1262.2s - 1270.0s]: into that over the years, what I've noticed is that all those different peoples were subjugated and

[1270.0s - 1276.0s]: subdued at different points in time. And one of the things I like to equip about, although it's

[1276.0s - 1282.9s]: serious, you know, for those of us who think the Roman Empire failed, we perhaps don't quite understand

[1282.9s - 1293.8s]: history because of exactly that moment that Constantine marked in the 300s. And I think there's

[1293.8s - 1299.8s]: a big invitation for all of us in this moment right now as modern human beings communicating with

[1299.8s - 1307.1s]: these incredible global communication technologies to really pause for a moment and to go inside and

[1307.1s - 1315.6s]: to get in touch with that form of violence that almost all of our ancestors have experienced in one

[1315.6s - 1323.5s]: way, shape or form, and to own it and to also recognize that while we have that that side in our

[1323.5s - 1329.5s]: backgrounds and history that has been victim, we also often very often have that side that was

[1329.5s - 1338.2s]: the oppressor and the subjugator. And it seems to me that Karen of one of the real deep spiritual

[1338.2s - 1344.5s]: opportunities in this for us as individuals is to open our eyes and really take a good look at

[1344.5s - 1352.1s]: that aspect of our reality and then to start asking the questions, well, how can I start to heal this?

[1352.7s - 1363.2s]: How can I start to live differently? How can I start to approach the way I'm thinking differently?

[1363.5s - 1370.6s]: Right? I think it evokes a lot of different rich questions. And I'm curious, what do you see when

[1370.6s - 1376.8s]: you're working with students and classrooms? Are you seeing a lot of aha moments? Is it more of a

[1376.8s - 1383.4s]: slow-steeping? What do you observe with people as they're awakening to this?

[1385.7s - 1391.9s]: That's so interesting. Thank you for what you said and I really agree with you. I think we,

[1392.4s - 1398.7s]: you know, people in our culture and our time tend to go to polarity very quickly.

[1399.3s - 1407.9s]: And yet it is a metaphysical and spiritual truth that there is a wholeness and a oneness at the

[1407.9s - 1419.1s]: center of this life experience. And if you are trying to separate yourself or trying to separate

[1419.1s - 1424.9s]: from others, there will be an intrusion of the truth and the reality that there isn't that

[1424.9s - 1432.5s]: separation actually. And if you can, and the healing work and the power really is, you know,

[1432.7s - 1438.5s]: Tick-Not-Hon, the Buddhist teacher said, we are here to awaken to the illusion of our separateness.

[1440.9s - 1450.7s]: I think sometimes about the particular kind of thought forms that have become more common in the

[1450.7s - 1458.1s]: Judeo-Christian tradition. Some people don't like that term, Judeo-Christian, because they rightly

[1458.1s - 1466.1s]: point out that the Jewish tradition stands on its own. But by that, I mean how through

[1467.2s - 1472.4s]: Christianity in this country it's been interpreted, drawing also from what we call the Old Testament.

[1472.4s - 1483.8s]: In any event, there is a concept of justice that is very big. And justice is through the past

[1483.8s - 1488.9s]: years of interfaith dialogue, one of the interesting things that I have learned is that it's not

[1488.9s - 1498.1s]: as resonant a concept in East Asian or in Indigenous traditions. It doesn't mean there's no such thing

[1498.1s - 1505.6s]: as right and wrong or what justice implies. But as the way that it's used, that we're used to

[1505.6s - 1511.0s]: using it, it's not as resonant, there are things like balance and harmony, there are other beautiful

[1511.7s - 1521.7s]: words that are used that have a very different connotation than justice. So what I wanted to say is that

[1521.7s - 1530.9s]: there are times and classrooms where people I think really want, really gravitate towards a kind of

[1530.9s - 1538.7s]: there are bad guys and if we isolate them and condemn them, everything will be fine. It's a

[1538.7s - 1545.7s]: thought form that many of us have and even your personal life, you know, your family, your community,

[1545.7s - 1551.6s]: it's just a human nature thing. And so I think that what we've done is to easily fall

[1551.6s - 1560.1s]: into that on a society level. It's it's it's just much more powerful and healing. I think when

[1560.1s - 1566.4s]: we interrogate that a little bit more. So when Martin Luther King said famously,

[1566.8s - 1574.0s]: injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere, that I think is quite similar to the Tick-Not-Hon

[1574.7s - 1581.4s]: statement of we are here to awaken to the illusion of our separateness. So it's not only that it's

[1581.4s - 1587.7s]: unfair to these group to certain groups of people if something happens disproportionately, it's

[1587.7s - 1593.6s]: that it will impact the whole. It will. Just like in the climate crisis is teaching us that,

[1594.4s - 1598.3s]: those three empty chairs that I mentioned in the beginning, you know, you don't pay attention

[1598.3s - 1604.3s]: to them. It's going to threaten the whole. And it's true in in different on different layers,

[1605.1s - 1609.3s]: different levels. So I think that you know, in answer to your original question,

[1609.9s - 1615.1s]: in classrooms it's very interesting people are coming from really different places. But there

[1615.1s - 1623.9s]: is a kind of pattern of sort of holding these things together, you know, yes, there are there are

[1623.9s - 1632.5s]: these major issues of oppression that must be dealt with and faced. And like James Baldwin said,

[1632.7s - 1639.8s]: you know, not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed unless it is

[1639.8s - 1647.3s]: faced. So we have to face them. At the same time, we have to be able to hold that wholeness and

[1647.3s - 1658.1s]: understand that to kind of place blame and cast aside, whole cultures or groups of people in

[1658.1s - 1662.7s]: history is not going to be the ultimate truth. The problem with it is that it's not the ultimate

[1662.7s - 1669.5s]: truth. So we these are theological questions and metaphysical questions, you know, going back to the

[1670.0s - 1674.7s]: there are always other dimensions of this to explore, going back to the history in Europe of

[1675.6s - 1681.3s]: of empire and its effect on our archaeological mindset today to go back to you know, the

[1681.3s - 1687.6s]: Middle Ages in Europe and even before then. It's interesting also to note that there were many

[1687.6s - 1695.4s]: women who were keepers of ceremonies and traditions and spirituality. So part of this also was to

[1695.4s - 1702.2s]: displace the feminine and to take the feminine out of the the the sense of who is a keeper of

[1702.2s - 1711.3s]: ceremony and sacred works. And of course, you know, we still live with that today and it's I think

[1711.3s - 1717.4s]: important for us to think about the impact that that theology has had even people who consider

[1717.4s - 1724.5s]: themselves secular have nonetheless often internalized the idea that we have a male god and a female

[1724.5s - 1732.6s]: earth just by virtue of absorbing literature and culture. It's just so deep in there. So what are

[1732.6s - 1738.8s]: the implications of that and how do we how do we look clearly at it in order to change it? So it's

segments.text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron Perry. And today we're
visiting with Karenna Gore. Hey, Karenna. Hi, Aaron. Thank you so much for having me on
the Y on Earth Podcast, which is great. It's a real pleasure. And I'm thrilled we can
talk with you, especially given what's going on in the world right now. And I want to get to that.
But first, let me introduce you to our audience for those who don't know you yet. So Karenna Gore is
the founder and director of the Center for Earth Ethics at Union Theological Seminary. The Center
for Earth Ethics bridges the worlds of religion, academia, policy, and culture to discern and pursue
the changes that are necessary to stop ecological destruction and create a society that values the
long-term health of the whole. She is also an ex-officio member of the Faculty of the Earth Institute
at Columbia University. Ms. Gore's previous experience includes serving as Director of Union
Forum at Union Theological Seminary, legal work at Simpson, Thacher, and Bartlett in the legal center
of sanctuary for families and serving as Director of Community Affairs for the Association to
Benefit Children and River Keeper. She has also worked as a writer and as the author of Lighting the
Way, Nine Women who changed modern America. Ms. Gore is a graduate of Harvard College, Columbia
Law School, and Union Theological Seminary. She lives in New York City with her three children.
Now, you live in New York City ordinarily, but presently you're not there because why? What's
going on in the world? Well, in this time, this pandemic of COVID-19, coronavirus,
when the school shut down and people were asked to work remotely, I'm one of those and well aware of
the privileged nature of this who was able to go out of the city to a place in the Catskills.
That I have shared with my former husband and I have my kids up here that are doing school
from up here and I'm doing work from up here. So I'm in the Catskills and the Western Catskills
and I apologize if the Wi-Fi drops off by the way because it is a bit spotty, but that's where I am
and I really appreciate being able to spend this time with you and your viewers when we can
really reflect on so much that's going on right now in the world. Yeah, absolutely, Karen,
and I just want to give a little teaser to the audience that we're going to be sharing some
special projects and links a little later in the discussion that are going live right now
in the context of corona and COVID and everything that's happening. So I want to make sure folks
catch that and it's so interesting to me too that so much of your work centers around
relationship with Earth, with planet, with biosphere and you do that from one of the largest and
most densely populated cities in the world, certainly in the United States. And I'm just curious
as a way to kind of give us grounded in our discussion today, what does Earth ethics mean?
And what does that mean in the context of education?
Well, thank you for that question. Ethics is defined differently depending on who's doing the ethics,
but essentially it is questions of right and wrong or good and evil or just or unjust.
It's different from law. In some we want our ethics to match up with our laws, it's wrong to
kill someone, it's also illegal, but ethics is also, it's really most important during those times
when deep sense of right and wrong is out of step with the law and also out of step with
social norms, which is another component that we look at. So right now with the circumstances
that were in ecologically, we have to acknowledge and face the fact that the drivers of ecological
destruction are for the most part perfectly legal and in line with social norms. So ethics
becomes especially important in terms of thinking about the Earth, how we relate to nature, to this
planet. We are coming up on the anniversary, the 50th anniversary of the first Earth Day.
And we're in a situation where we have a looming climate crisis. I was born in the early 1970s and
in my lifetime the human population has doubled and the population of wildlife has been cut in half.
We've lost about half the world's forests. We know the bleaching of the coral reefs and the
depletion of aquifers of groundwater. We face an extinction crisis. There are so many ways in which
are the way our society is organized right now is putting great strain on the Earth. And so Earth
ethics looks at that. And there are some deep roots to how we got here. And I know you've explored
some of this on your other podcasts. So we look at those and think about what is the circle of moral
concern that people normally think about? And I have a friend at the Church of Sweden who says that
in any room where there are decisions made about energy policy, environmental policy, there should
be three empty chairs designated for those who are most impacted and least likely to have a voice.
And those should be for the poor and marginalized peoples of the world, for future generations,
and for all non-human life. And when you think about it, if we had paid attention to those three,
we would not be in this crisis. So Earth ethics is a construct to think about how do we change
who we're paying attention to that sense of moral accountability to include those three empty chairs?
In terms of education, it is also a very big challenge to try to conceive of how we can become
ecological citizens in this world. Many people don't know, for example, what watershed they're in,
where the waste goes that you throw out in the garbage or you flush down the toilet,
where the power comes from when you turn on the lights. And yet these are all connected
to ecological realities and systems and to other communities that if we're more aware of,
then we'll be able to change for the better.
It's so interesting to recognize and talk about and make express that in many respects,
what we might be compelled to do, what we might find to be a moral imperative,
doesn't necessarily match with social norms. And it makes me think about the civil rights movement,
especially around the middle of the 20th century. And with amazing leaders and a whole bunch of
dedicated individuals whose names we don't know as well as somebody like Reverend Martin Luther King,
for example, it was the hard work of a whole lot of folks in a lot of different communities
who helped to transform the social norms. And of course, it doesn't have an overnight,
it's not like flipping a switch, but I think it's fair to say that we've made some very real progress
on that front and that it might provide a hopeful pattern for us to think about in terms of
the ecological challenges that we're facing. Absolutely. I think that's a very rich connection to
draw. And it is indeed a time when we can think about that the deep sense of right and wrong
was out of step with laws and with social norms. And so some of the movements, the lunch counter
sit-ins, the freedom rides were about unmasking the unjustness, the unethical nature of those laws.
And there were, as you say, people behind the scenes or in the grassroots layer of that movement,
like Septima Clark is one example who ran citizenship schools in the south and the people that
went through and trained to know basic civic rights and also strategies of solidarity,
of coordinating, of organizing among the people that went through those classes was Rosa Parks.
Another one was John Lewis. So there are people who didn't come out of nowhere, they came through
a movement and a type of education that was not at all top down, not at all based in kind of a
ivory tower academy, but based in generating consciousness and knowledge and experience among people.
So if we take that example in this time of ecological crisis, then we might be able to do the same thing.
Another thing about drawing that connection to the civil rights movement is to consider the role
that religion played. So we're based at a seminary, the Center for Earth Ethics, and it has a very
interfaith tradition within it. And we don't forward one religious point of view, but we take religion
very seriously for a few reasons. For one thing, we look not only at the role of religion for good,
but also the role that it's played for ill. And there are some real theological questions
about the illusion of our separation from nature, how we even talk about climate and environment,
and sometimes we haven't recognized that it's actually the air and the water and the soil that are
part of our bodies. But another thing about engaging religion is to look at what moves and
motivates people in their behavior, what can draw from deeper values. And of course, in the civil rights
movement, we saw that. We saw that from the language that came as well as from the organizing spaces
in the churches. And of course, that was especially true in the African-American community.
But across the board, abolitionism and civil rights organizing started also in white and black
communities in spaces where people were drawing from deep within faith traditions.
Yeah, so beautiful. Wow, you just got me firing in a bunch of different directions at once,
hearing you connect these dots the way that you just did. That's really wonderful and potent.
And it strikes me that one of the most significant challenges and opportunities we face in the west,
particularly in the United States, is really recognizing the deep roots of the philosophical,
the religious disconnection from the natural living world. And of course, there's a whole bunch of
literature, scholarship on how that relates both to environmental degradation and incredible social
injustice. And whether we're looking at the very challenging,
derisive critique of Nietzsche 140 or 50 years ago, or looking at more recently the beautiful book
by Thomas Barry called, what is it, the fate of the earth in the Christian future or something like that?
There's the dream that we were going to make the great work. Yeah.
Yeah, there's this very big conversation that's been unfolding over generations.
And it seems to me we're now living at a moment when how this conversation unfolds and in a sense
resolves itself in the next few years is incredibly significant in determining what our
near and midterm future is going to look like. And I'm curious in your role as an educator,
how deep do you go into that history? How far back do you go? What threads are you pulling through
for your students to help awaken them to the reality that we're living in right now?
Oh, thank you. Well, I, and I know of your interest in this and I've heard you speak and
and interview others and so I really appreciate your work on this Aaron and happy to
to be part of that conversation. Well, for one thing, let me just say that the Center for
Earth Ethics really grew out of this conference that we had. I went to Union and got a master's
kind of mid-life mid-career and then I had a general public programming job there and
we're based as a seminary based in New York City. So the idea was that when the United Nations
meets every year, perhaps we could have something at Union that deals with religion and spirituality
and how it's affected how it relates to whatever the UN happens to be focused on.
Because the UN for good reasons, mostly doesn't directly engage religion but religion drives so much
in the world, both for good and ill. And so anyway, I was there in September 2014,
the Secretary General at the time, Bon Kimu, called the Climate Summit. It happens now every year,
but to engage civil society because this climate crisis is so urgent and yet governments haven't
been able to, this was before the Paris Agreement, get it together to get that agreement and the
idea was to engage civil society, including which includes business, it includes different sectors,
but religion was one component. So we were able to have this conference at Union,
called Religions for the Earth. And I was an organizer of that. And after that,
we founded the center. So I tell you that background because I wanted to be able to engage
and interreligious dialogue in a good way. And it was very clear that Indigenous traditions were
important to that and had not always been included in conventional interfaith dialogue.
So looking at the history, having some of those conversations, doing some of that reading,
looking more closely at the history of colonization and its relationship to ecological destruction,
caused me to understand the history of the doctrine of discovery in this country.
And that comes out of the fact that in the mid-15th century, the European nations were wanting to
explore and colonize and extract from, particularly the Americas and Africa. And from the Vatican,
there was this papal that was that series of them that said to conquer vanquishing subdued
all the flora and fauna and said that the non-Christian people, meaning all the native people,
were part of the flora and fauna. So we look at that as a root cause of this sense,
first of all, connecting white supremacy to ecological destruction and the theology behind it,
because it was explicitly coming from a place of Christianity. So that's important. Then if you go
deeper back in time even, it's very interesting to look at how this happened in the first place
with the conversion of the emperor Constantine, the Roman emperor to Christianity in the early fourth
century. So that became the marriage of Christianity, which as we know, this wasn't the teachings of
Jesus or the texts of the Bible. We're not already linked to this kind of empire and colonization
behaviors, but the, although you can have an interesting discussion about the theology there,
but in an event when Constantine converted and there was this push to make, to Christianize Europe,
we can look at one source in particular that I think is really interesting. And many people
know it already, but it's called, there was an essay in 1967 by a medieval historian named Lin
White, who wrote the historic roots of our ecological crisis. And he said in that essay that the greatest
psychic revolution in human history was the victory of Christianity over paganism in Europe.
And so that takes it back even further in time than the doctrine of discovery to show the theological
roots of a kind of doctrine that said that what is sacred cannot see your landscape as sacred, your
ceremonies, a kind of fear and of paganism. And you still see that in a lot of the conversations
and the kind of culture war that people have developed around environmentalism or concern for
the climate that somehow your tree hugger, that your worshipping nature. And that is that deep
fear of paganism that goes that far back. So we try to look at, we try to look at those histories
in order to see where that's coming from in order to look clearly at the role that the church
has played, which of course is not all for ill. There has been a lot of really beautiful theology
and work within Christianity and other religions. But in a classroom, so we do, we give classes at
union. That's one thing that we're able to do. And it's wonderful to work with union students.
So we can do that, we can do that reading, and then we can also talk to people who are living in
communities now. And that's really what's most important is to hear from people, for example,
when the conflict at Standing Rock happened some years ago. And we could hear from
Lakota people who wanted to voice what that was about from their perspective. So we try to combine
lived experiences with those scholarly texts and look at the root causes and then create
earth ethics from there. It's absolutely beautiful. So beautiful. You have me reflecting on my own
heritage. And one of the things I've noticed talking with different folks is that in many communities,
when we're talking about indigenous peoples, when we're talking about colonialism, for a lot of us,
that's this experience that's way over there with people we don't know, or folks were not connected to.
And being the ad mixture of different lineages that I am, which include some mohawk Native American
ancestry, some Slovenian ancestry, some German ancestry, some Celtic ancestry. As I have dug
into that over the years, what I've noticed is that all those different peoples were subjugated and
subdued at different points in time. And one of the things I like to equip about, although it's
serious, you know, for those of us who think the Roman Empire failed, we perhaps don't quite understand
history because of exactly that moment that Constantine marked in the 300s. And I think there's
a big invitation for all of us in this moment right now as modern human beings communicating with
these incredible global communication technologies to really pause for a moment and to go inside and
to get in touch with that form of violence that almost all of our ancestors have experienced in one
way, shape or form, and to own it and to also recognize that while we have that that side in our
backgrounds and history that has been victim, we also often very often have that side that was
the oppressor and the subjugator. And it seems to me that Karen of one of the real deep spiritual
opportunities in this for us as individuals is to open our eyes and really take a good look at
that aspect of our reality and then to start asking the questions, well, how can I start to heal this?
How can I start to live differently? How can I start to approach the way I'm thinking differently?
Right? I think it evokes a lot of different rich questions. And I'm curious, what do you see when
you're working with students and classrooms? Are you seeing a lot of aha moments? Is it more of a
slow-steeping? What do you observe with people as they're awakening to this?
That's so interesting. Thank you for what you said and I really agree with you. I think we,
you know, people in our culture and our time tend to go to polarity very quickly.
And yet it is a metaphysical and spiritual truth that there is a wholeness and a oneness at the
center of this life experience. And if you are trying to separate yourself or trying to separate
from others, there will be an intrusion of the truth and the reality that there isn't that
separation actually. And if you can, and the healing work and the power really is, you know,
Tick-Not-Hon, the Buddhist teacher said, we are here to awaken to the illusion of our separateness.
I think sometimes about the particular kind of thought forms that have become more common in the
Judeo-Christian tradition. Some people don't like that term, Judeo-Christian, because they rightly
point out that the Jewish tradition stands on its own. But by that, I mean how through
Christianity in this country it's been interpreted, drawing also from what we call the Old Testament.
In any event, there is a concept of justice that is very big. And justice is through the past
years of interfaith dialogue, one of the interesting things that I have learned is that it's not
as resonant a concept in East Asian or in Indigenous traditions. It doesn't mean there's no such thing
as right and wrong or what justice implies. But as the way that it's used, that we're used to
using it, it's not as resonant, there are things like balance and harmony, there are other beautiful
words that are used that have a very different connotation than justice. So what I wanted to say is that
there are times and classrooms where people I think really want, really gravitate towards a kind of
there are bad guys and if we isolate them and condemn them, everything will be fine. It's a
thought form that many of us have and even your personal life, you know, your family, your community,
it's just a human nature thing. And so I think that what we've done is to easily fall
into that on a society level. It's it's it's just much more powerful and healing. I think when
we interrogate that a little bit more. So when Martin Luther King said famously,
injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere, that I think is quite similar to the Tick-Not-Hon
statement of we are here to awaken to the illusion of our separateness. So it's not only that it's
unfair to these group to certain groups of people if something happens disproportionately, it's
that it will impact the whole. It will. Just like in the climate crisis is teaching us that,
those three empty chairs that I mentioned in the beginning, you know, you don't pay attention
to them. It's going to threaten the whole. And it's true in in different on different layers,
different levels. So I think that you know, in answer to your original question,
in classrooms it's very interesting people are coming from really different places. But there
is a kind of pattern of sort of holding these things together, you know, yes, there are there are
these major issues of oppression that must be dealt with and faced. And like James Baldwin said,
you know, not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed unless it is
faced. So we have to face them. At the same time, we have to be able to hold that wholeness and
understand that to kind of place blame and cast aside, whole cultures or groups of people in
history is not going to be the ultimate truth. The problem with it is that it's not the ultimate
truth. So we these are theological questions and metaphysical questions, you know, going back to the
there are always other dimensions of this to explore, going back to the history in Europe of
of empire and its effect on our archaeological mindset today to go back to you know, the
Middle Ages in Europe and even before then. It's interesting also to note that there were many
women who were keepers of ceremonies and traditions and spirituality. So part of this also was to
displace the feminine and to take the feminine out of the the the sense of who is a keeper of
ceremony and sacred works. And of course, you know, we still live with that today and it's I think
important for us to think about the impact that that theology has had even people who consider
